Through ice-breaker exercises, goal-oriented activities, and question and answer sessions, the Link Crew teams introduce important skills and encourage a motivated mindset. One of the program‚Äôs greatest strengths though is simply helping freshmen make connections with experienced students, providing them with someone to turn to if and when they face a challenge adapting to or navigating their new school. Taking the first step into a new building can be daunting, but the Link Crew members ‚Äì the upperclassmen who volunteer and attend training sessions to lead the freshmen orientation and beyond - help make that transition easier so that incoming students can begin their high school years more enthusiastically, confidently, and productively.

This year, all Jackson students will receive a bagful of instruments, scaled to fit their little hands. Youth group members and adult volunteers from the First Presbyterian Church in Batavia helped Jackson music teacher Lisa Gilebarto put together hundreds of the music-making packages ‚Äì enough for each Jackson student to receive one. While the District‚Äôs music department was able to purchase small maracas and tambourines, the gallon-size bags, donated by Walmart, also contain drums made from plastic containers donated by First Presbyterian Church; and rhythm sticks made from dowel rods that were donated by Home Depot, Valu Home Center, and First Presbyterian Church, and then crafted to the proper size and smoothness by volunteers Bob Alwardt, Dave Paladino, Jane Haggett, and Joyce and Bob Saxer.
Ms. Gilebarto is looking forward to another fun year of making music with all of her Jackson students!

Today, the Batavia City Schools District released a comprehensive remote learning plan that addresses key components of successful hybrid and virtual learning for all stakeholders-students, parents and teachers.

These key components address social and emotional learning needs and its importance during remote learning; how families and students can connect with the school and teaching staff; student, teacher and parent expectations for all grade levels regarding instructional time; best practices surrounding hybrid and remote instruction; student engagement and collaboration; equity and flexibility and evaluation of student work.

Familiarity with this guide will ensure that all stakeholders in this endeavor are knowledgeable about their own particular role in the remote virtual learning model and can confidently move forward in yet another unique school year.

Our district has created a brief survey to better understand the perspectives and level of concern our stakeholders have regarding the reopening of our schools for students in September 2020.

The COVID-19 pandemic required significant action and disruption from our traditional face-to-face instructional model.

The information and data that is gathered from this survey will help our district best prepare and develop plans, protocols, and safety measures that are appropriate and align with our stakeholders' expectations. Our top priority is the health, safety, and welfare of our students, staff, and families.

Thank you for sharing feedback on these topics that relate to the reopening of schools in the Fall. As we receive more guidance and direction over the Summer from the Governor, health officials, and the NYS Education Department, we will work to create and implement the planning necessary to safely educate our students.

Three Months on the Farm!
While students may have had to spend a lot of time indoors and close to home during the school closure, many of JK‚Äôs fourth graders were able to take daily visits to the Rebisz Family Farm. Fourth grade teacher Joe Rebisz - with his wife Jocelyn and their six children - opened their homestead to the fourth graders via short videos that described life on their family farm. Each video was tied to a lesson, and topics included such things as incubating chicken and turkey eggs; chores on a farm; caring for and usefulness of animals such as horses, pigs, and goats; composting; gardening; making maple syrup; and recognizing edible wild plants. The lessons included additional informational resources as well as activities and projects from Mr. Rebisz and other fourth grade teachers. Many of the students were very much engaged with this learning experience and Mr. Rebisz said they produced excellent work on the assignments.

There are many things memorable about this year, but for fourth graders, this may be one of the favorite memories.

Welcome back to Alice Ann Benedict, who, having served on the Board of Education from 1995-2006 - including three terms as BOE president - was appointed this month to serve until the next election. She is filling the position vacated by Zachary Korzelius who, unfortunately, had to resign due to outside obligations.

A long-time homemaker and retired paralegal, Mrs. Benedict has strong ties to the Batavia City School District. Both she and her husband Wayne graduated from BHS, as did her three children. Now, one of her grandchildren is beginning the BCSD journey at Jackson Primary! Among her extended family, many are graduates of or currently enrolled in our schools. In addition, Mrs. Benedict chose ‚Äúlocal‚Äù for her post-high school studies and graduated with honors from Genesee Community College.

Mrs. Benedict says, ‚ÄúI have always been interested in the education of students of Batavia, at a fair cost to residents here. The BCSD is near and dear to my heart. I‚Äôd like to see it continue to improve, and I know I can help with that process.‚Äù

Dear Members of the Blue Devils School Community,

Today, Governor Cuomo extended our school closure for the remainder of the 2019-2020 school year. We will continue to provide our remote learning program for students for the duration of this closure. As we receive guidance from New York State, an official end date for our remote learning program will be announced. Additionally, we will continue with our food distribution for the duration of this closure. Plans for students to retrieve remaining personal belongings from schools will be communicated to families in the near future.

It is also our hope that we also will be able to provide our Batavia High Seniors opportunities to be celebrated but we will need further guidance on safety protocols and social distancing. We will continue to communicate information as decisions are made.

We wish all of the members of our school community good health and safety in these challenging times.

Thank you,

Superintendent Soler
